content.webTitle: Vigils for North Carolina students held across US: 'We're here for each other'

fields.headline: Vigils for North Carolina students held across US: 'We're here for each other'
fields.bodyText: Thousands paid their respects on Thursday as three Muslim students, Deah Barakat, Yusor Mohammad Abu-Salha, and her sister sister Razan Mohammad Abu-Salha were laid to rest in North Carolina, after they were shot dead by a neighbor. While police are investigtating as a motive a parking dispute with the killer, Craig Stephen Hicks, family, friends and allies are denouncing the shootings as a hate crime. On Wednesday, at least 3,000 people attended a candelight vigil at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. But the pain of the murders has spread far beyond the state. College students across the country swiftly organized prayer vigils, with several being led by members Muslim student associations. Below are just some such gatherings. University of Milwaukee, Wisconsin Students at UMW braved the bitter cold for an afternoon vigil on Thursday. Muslim Student Association president Firas Hamid told the local CBS affiliate: “I can imagine what their parents are going through. I can imagine if I were in their place, what my mom, what my grandma, what my family would be going through. So, it’s saddening and that’s why we’re trying to do this on their behalf.” Temple University, Pennsylvania More than a hundred students gathered at Temple’s Bell Tower, bringing with them candles and signs that read “Muslim Lives Matter”. “These are literally our brother and sisters, and it really hit us hard and we had to do some kind of action about it,” one student told Fox 29. A vigil also took place at the nearby University of Pennsylvania on Wednesday evening. University of Chicago About 50 UChicago students gathered. “To all the allies who were there in support: we need you to continue to show the love, compassion, and understanding that brought you to the vigil a few hours ago, that I saw in your faces as you listened to us grieve,” Maha Ahmed wrote on a Facebook event page. The Chicago Maroon, the university’s school newspaper, described the scene: The candlelit vigil outside Bartlett Dining Hall began with a welcome speech and prayer recited in both Arabic and English led by Imam Tahir Abdullah, assistant director of spiritual life and advisor for Muslim affairs at the university. “Gatherings like these are proof that faith and prayer and the space to worship in community with others are essential, not tangential, to human life,” Abdullah said. “Whether you come from Syria or Nigeria or the South Side of Chicago, your lineage, your community, your historical memory about where you come from is precious and must be preserved and protected.” University of California, Los Angeles According to the the Daily Bruin, nearly 100 people attended UCLA’s prayer vigil on Thursday evening. “We want to accomplish a sense of community, a sense of peace, to show that we’re here for each other,” student Damali Stennette told the paper.
